Filling an Interim Vacancy: When a seat on the Alabama Supreme Court becomes open in the middle of a justice’s term, the governor appoints a judicial candidate to the empty seat on the bench. The appointed justice holds office until Alabama’s next general election more than one year after she was appointed, unless the remainder of the seat’s term runs out before then. During the election, multiple candidates may vie for the seat in a partisan election. The elected justice serves a six-year term.

Additional Terms: A sitting justice approaching the end of her term may seek additional six-year terms through participating in a partisan election, where multiple candidates may vie for the seat.
